intro: Trachyspermum stictocarpum, commonly known as bishop's weed, is an annual herbaceous plant native to southern Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the carrot family. Its seeds are used in traditional medicine and as a spice, valued for their aromatic properties. Trachyspermum stictocarpum thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy plant in temperate climates.
